body:
Keep in mind that usage of Lambda expression also totally breaks fix-and-continue during debugging. It's a nice syntax suggar but until Hotspot folks fix the VM, class with lambdas does not allow to incrementally fix the code.

As for unit tests: they run on the master. So the only sane approach is to fix the code so that tests run again. But this PR is WIP, so OK. But before the PR is reviewed, I recommend to discard that commit from history.

The PR starts being hard to read, mixing (intentionally just) formatting changes with refactorings which actually have potential to break something. I recommend to separate those two actions into either separate commits, or separate PRs - it's easier to verify that refactoring did not change semantic if 90% of file is not whitespace-changed.

As for commit messages (personal opinion): I will not approve PR with messages like "for the queen", "fixing errors" (which actually deletes test code), or "order of maw". I believe that added confusion which outweights the fun of reading them.

Debugging, like making use of assert statements, is a relic of the past. Modern software in general has become far way to complex for being used with such features. But take it as my humble opinion. I've almost no idea, how a real project would look like, and what possibly can be done, if used cleverly by a true master.
I'm not sure that the for loop is useless. The int array that is modified is stored within the td.tag2Span map. See: https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/NETBEANS-278
Thank you.
What (if anything) is blocking this PR from being merged? (Just curious of how the PR process works for this project)

Took me some time to figure it out, since it's already late, but: It will be closed, and be available through the archive of closed pull requests. Which is an awesome feature, currently available on the top left corner of this table: https://github.com/apache/incubator-netbeans/pulls

It's a grasp on immortality for all the individuals involved, until it is abused by someone. :feelsgood:

Hi @dtrebbien , this PR has 13 commits, will you please squash them for review as described at https://cwiki.apache.org/confluence/pages/viewpage.action?pageId=74681408 ?

@cowwoc  All PRs must be reviewed before being merged.
Okay, I have squashed the 12 cleanup commits together and kept the bug fix commit separate, for ease of review.

Hi @dtrebbien would you please remove all //NOI18N comments?

//NOI18N comments are useful in files to be translated, to aid translator distinguish between literals and strings that need translation. This class is not expected to be translated, so there's no need to comment all literals with NOI18N comments.
Thanks,
Antonio
I have removed the ones I added.

Hi again,
Also please try to keep  type information visible as much as possible. So for instance this:
`fieldGroup = new ArrayList<JCVariableDecl>();`
is much more readable than
`fieldGroup = new ArrayList<>();`
As it clearly states the type of the collection and avoids future reviewers to look up the type of "fieldGroup". There's no harm in keeping type information explicit.
I have added back type parameters to non-variable-initializer expressions.

Thanks everyone, I had a closer look at the change and fixed the test regressions. Apart from the two issues reported by @matthiasblaesing, there was a missing create option in NbLogging. The PR also revealed a bug in the SystemFileSystemTest which was failing due to leaked file streams. Fixed the test.
Do I need to squash?

Hi @dtrebbien test files need an ASF license header. Once done I'll try to run tests cases during the coming week.
Thanks,
Antonio

I've built the zip file and compared it to the repository contents. These are the differences:

```
$incubating$ diff -qr . ../incubator-netbeans/
Only in ../incubator-netbeans/: .git
Only in ../incubator-netbeans/: .gitattributes
Only in ../incubator-netbeans/: .gitignore
Only in ../incubator-netbeans/: .travis.yml
Only in .: DEPENDENCIES
Only in ../incubator-netbeans/: form.binding
Only in ../incubator-netbeans/: hibernate
Only in ../incubator-netbeans/: hibernate4lib
Only in ../incubator-netbeans/: libs.svnClientAdapter.svnkit
Only in ../incubator-netbeans/nbbuild/external: vanilla-javac-api.jar
Only in ../incubator-netbeans/nbbuild/external: vanilla-javac-impl.jar
Only in ../incubator-netbeans/: o.jdesktop.beansbinding
Only in ../incubator-netbeans/: travis-check-line-endings.sh
```

The generated zip file contains a DEPENDENCIES file not present in the repository, but I think this is perfectly OK. The offending previous jar files (jhall et al.) are not present now.

+1

@jlahoda There are some minor files in nbbuild/external, I'm not sure we want to keep these (nbbuild/external/langtools-9-license.txt is a GPL license header).

```
incubating$ find nbbuild/external/
nbbuild/external/
nbbuild/external/langtools-9-license.txt
nbbuild/external/findbugs
nbbuild/external/findbugs/build.xml
nbbuild/external/binaries-list
nbbuild/external/apitest-license.txt
```

Thank you for your work. However, this template file already exists[1]. (#174)
The following settings can be used instead of it:
```
project.license=apache20-netbeans
```
If netbeans modules are opened in Apache NetBeans, the license header is added automatically.

[1] https://github.com/apache/incubator-netbeans/blob/master/apisupport.ant/src/org/netbeans/modules/apisupport/project/resources/license-apache20-netbeans.txt

Ouch, I wasn't aware of your PR, Junichi.   

Our approaches are different, though.  I'n my mind there isn't a template for a "NetBeans license", but one for ASF projects in general .... which NetBeans project happens to use.  With this approach it shows up in "Tools --> Templates --> Licenses" and it can be used just as well for those who use the NetBeans IDE to contribute to Tomcat, Cassandra, Maven, or whatever.  I'll see if the two approaches can be merged so that we can get the best of both. 

My PR definitely shouldn't be merged as-is.

No problem :) Probably, we should just change the file name and display name.
- from "license-apache20-netbeans.txt" to "license-apache20-asf.txt"
- from "NetBeans Apache License 2.0" to "The ASF - Apache License 2.0"

If you want to do that, please feel free to do that. Otherwise, I'll do that :)

@junichi11. Yes, agree on approach. I need to reverse some of PR174, so that the template text file exist in `projectui` project instead of `apisupport.ant` project. 

I also need to understand why you turn the header into a Javadoc comment:

```
<#if licenseFirst??>
    <#if licenseFirst == "/*">
        <#assign licenseFirst="/**">
```

See [NETBEANS-161](https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/NETBEANS-161). Or do I misunderstand what that lingo means?  I think it may be due to the fact that you made your PR in October and probably modeled after the then current state of affairs. It was in November that we realized that we had done a mistake on all Apache NetBeans source files and reversed that in [PR282](https://github.com/apache/incubator-netbeans/pull/282).

Other than that I know what I need to do to get the best of both. :-)

> See NETBEANS-161.

@lbruun I know it :) See #288
Apologies. Missed that.
No problem.

@junichi11. Great if you can review latest amendment I did.  The provider of the license template is now `projectui` rather than `apisupport.ant`. Also, your license template file has been carried over as-is (mine didn't have the add-an-empty-line-if-xml feature).
I'm curious why this wasn't (or was it) a problem in 8.2? I.e., this problem didn't occur there, did it?

In 8.2, there were no (JDK) modules (and only one unnamed package). I didn't check, but the test was probably written as:
t.owner == syms.unnamedPackage

So it didn't fail the same way. While we could just fix the test, I think this whole code is just a remnant of handling of FQN names (i.e. printing simple names where possible) in VeryPretty/WidthEstimator. I don't think we are using that now. VeryPretty/WidthEstimator should print the trees as they are. The FQN handling is now done using QualIdents and ImportAnalysis2.

This also means, that an ICLA is necessary. The required header (emphasis mine):

> **Licensed to the Apache Software Foundation (ASF) under one
> or more contributor license agreements.**  See the NOTICE file
> distributed with this work for additional information
> regarding copyright ownership.  The ASF licenses this file
> to you under the Apache License, Version 2.0 (the
> "License"); you may not use this file except in compliance
> with the License.  You may obtain a copy of the License at
> 
>   http://www.apache.org/licenses/LICENSE-2.0
> 
> Unless required by applicable law or agreed to in writing,
> software distributed under the License is distributed on an
> "AS IS" BASIS, WITHOUT WARRANTIES OR CONDITIONS OF ANY
> KIND, either express or implied.  See the License for the
> specific language governing permissions and limitations
> under the License.

and for individuals this would be the ICLA. This is not dissimilar to the situation before the donation (OCA) and also is sensible when you consider, that legal requirements change. At this point in time the ASF requires ALv2, but before that was the ALv1 and so relicensing was necessary and it might be needed in the future again. If the ASF holds the copyright/a license relicensing is easy: The PMC can just update the copyright headers and is done. If the ASF would not hold the copy you'd need the agreement of all copyright holders. The merges without an ICLA are under the "small contributions/fixes don't establish a copyright" assumption, 

This is valuable work and really appreciated so @dtrebbien please reevaluate your decision not to sign the apache ICLA.
@lbruun Thank you for your contribution! Merged.

So, just to make sure. The tags `code-cleanup` and `work-in-progress` seem to mark somewhat suspicious pull requests. You likely want to concentrate on other things; probably more useful stuff, than review and education. I will close this. Good luck!

I am not going to sign the Apache Foundation's ICLA.

Here's what I can do: I am dedicating the test code files to the Public Domain. Therefore, the Apache Software Foundation and anyone else can do whatever they want with it. I will add the required license header to the new test files and update the "caret positions" in the unit tests.
Done. ASF license headers added.

Thanks for looking at this, Jarda. A question though: would synthesizing the interface help the class to link? There is already code that does that in "java.source.base/src/org/netbeans/modules/java/source/NoJavacHelper.java". Keeping this stuff on one place would help to drop all the workaround when we stop supporting JDK 8. (And may also help other features that would run to this problem.)
This is tracked as jira issue [[NETBEANS-258]](https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/NETBEANS-258). The fix works, but Jan has a point for long term considerations.

@cp7781 there is also `<antcall target="finish-build"/>` on line 199, which got broken by removing the "finish-build" umbrella target in commit bcb22df8139.
See yourself by invoking "ant update" (see the original PR's comment) on sources without the fix.
The build failure should be fixed by PR #371.
Congratulations ! You won the "first API author" contest this year.

Re. `NoJavacHelper.java` - yes, it seems better to have a `hasWorkingJavac` method, than putting the names of classes all around the code base. On the other hand, this is not what my patch does. It just catches `LinkageError`. This kind of `try/catch` code is hard to put into a centralized place, right?

@JaroslavTulach, please note that I didn't ask to use the hasWorkingJavac method, or a centralized place to put try-catch (LinkageError). I asked if *synthesizing* the interface would help. And, indeed, it appears it would: [synthesize-directives.txt](https://github.com/apache/incubator-netbeans/files/1632727/synthesize-directives.txt)

I guess I don't see how scattering catches for LinkageErrors around the codebase is better than having a centralized place where all the needed stuff is injected. What exactly is the process to remove all the catches? Or will we just leave them in forever masking any LinkageErrors whether related to this or not?
The dependencies are fixed. Time to integrate, I guess.
This is the first time I hear about NetBeans using "synthesizing". I apologize for misunderstanding. Feel free to do whatever you want with my integration.

I have significantly overhauled the modifications to NPECheck, based on @sdedic's [concern](https://github.com/apache/incubator-netbeans/pull/314#discussion_r154876644) about the broad-scope heuristic that I was using in the previous iteration of this patch.

There is now a user-configurable "nullability of fields" preference, which allows the user to customize which fields (identified by their fully-qualified name) would be considered null, non-null, or possibly null by NPECheck. This mechanism also allows for a set of base mappings, stored in `BASE_NULLABILITY_OF_FIELDS`, that are referred to if the user has not specifically configured a field. Right now, I have only added mappings for `java.lang.Boolean.TRUE` and `java.lang.Boolean.FALSE`, but I will add a lot more if you all like this new approach.

I was also thinking about "nullability of method return values" which would allow the user to customize whether specifically-identified methods return null, non-null, or possibly null values. This will be slightly more complex to support than "nullability of fields", so I have not done this, but if you all like the "nullability of fields" idea, then I will certainly work on this extension.
NOI18N added and commits squashed.

Changing label "Code cleanup" with "enhancement", as I think it better reflects the intent.
@mdindoffer is this ready for a new review then?

By the way, to see the new UI for editing the "nullability of fields" preference, go to **NetBeans > Preferences**. Click on the Editor tab, and then the Hints subtab. In the tree on the left, navigate to and click Probable Bugs > Null Pointer Dereference:
![screen shot 2018-01-16 at 9 00 19 am](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/277166/35001835-9cd0fc42-fa9c-11e7-9659-3dc2e8b62978.png)
Yes, ready for review.
Because there are now not very many cleanup-type changes, I went ahead and squashed the two commits together.
I'm currently build the current state. There were two failing tests (not caused by this changeset) and I'll now check the state after I merged to master. If the build runs clean, I'll push it..
I reviewed it but had not time to run unit tests. Looks good.

@mdindoffer I came to the same conclusion as @vieiro and merged the changes. I squashed the commits and added two commits already mentioned.

Thank you working on this.
Looks good. java.editor tests run well, I'll run java.source.base tests later on (these are heavy to run).
Will this pull request work, if the source repository is missing due to time passed by? :skull:

Ran the following 5 tests in java.source. base (that use CasualDiff.java) with success:
- org/netbeans/modules/java/source/save/DiffFacilityTest.java
- org/netbeans/api/java/source/gen/ConstructorTest.java
- org/netbeans/api/java/source/gen/CommentsTest.java
- org/netbeans/api/java/source/gen/ParameterizedTypeTest.java
- org/netbeans/api/java/source/gen/CompilationUnitTest.java

So the code is  donated to the ASF that will licensed under the APLv2. I think we're all set!
I'd appreciate a final approval by @matthiasblaesing before committing.

@dtrebbien thx for the explanation, the refactoring was needed to added the ActionIds, I tried it before I refactored the code, because that wasn't my intention. So I changed the code a bit and got it working, while I created new actions in external classes. Maybe I made a mistake and it would work right inside as nested classes but now I think it is a bit cleaner.
@sdedic thx for reviewing, I will have a look later.

BTW, regarding my remark:

> But if you instantiate the action manually with new SplitDocumentVerticallyAction how is the shortcut set? Maybe I'm missing something really obvious.

I believe there may be 2 instances of the same action. One added manually with `new` which basically does not have a keyboard shortcut and another one added by the NetBeans infra which does have the binding. My confusion was probably assuming there is a single instance.

I would appreciate somebody confirming this or not, etc. because it was not obvious to me.

Yeah so the actions, which are added manually via `new` are for the contextmenu of an opened tab
![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/795658/35099696-4353e148-fc59-11e7-8832-b2ae01c28dea.png)


and for the menu 

Window -> Configure Window -> Split Document.
![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/795658/35099674-2f5ff712-fc59-11e7-9e5a-56d2fc2eacf1.png)

Those actions where added before now I only create a new instance, but yes maybe it could be done even better. Changes are appreciated too.

I agree with @vieiro I ran through the full unittest suite and found increased test counts and the same failing tests (fixing these is a different problem). In general this looks good. I'll go ahead and merge it in.
I've restarted the Travis build.
Hi @dtrebbien  is this ready for review?
Yes
Merged - thank you.
OK, merging, will then be part of rc3 of Beta 9.0.
Will need to squash again, if this is approved.
Will squash once approved.

Why was this merged? According to the legal FAQ:
https://www.apache.org/legal/resolved.html#category-a
MIT is whitelisted and the license terms are perfectly met. The license must stay in place and the unittests are only delivered in source - there is nothing to remove here.
Fantastic! I
I think one more addition could be to add a URL to each category, with the URL pointing to the related Apache guidelines for more details.

Works good on my system under JDK 9.0.1. Before applying this patch i had code completion times ranging from 15 to 30 seconds (lots of maven dependencies) . With this patch the code completion usually pops up after 1 to 3 seconds.

I still have the issue that code completion sometimes is instant (some milliseconds, with/without patch) and sometimes it takes quite a lot longer, as if the index would be forgotten and rebuild from scratch - without even editing anything.

Seems fine, I think. I skimmed through the exclusions, and I think some would be better on some other places (e.g. have "*/test/{unit,qa-functional}/data" as "test data"), so I think fine to integrate, and then we can reorder/fix as needed.
OK.
Fixed formatting + NOI18N added to the introduced String
OK, merging, many thanks for doing this, @ebarboni. You are definitely the Rat master.

I did a local merge to master and build that. I found the problem fixed (nbjavac with java 8). I see a minor difference to netbeans 8.2: When a class file outside a jar is selected the navigator window in netbeans 8.2 shows the class name (no members), with netbeans 9 the navigator window remains empty. From my POV this is ok.

Without nbjavac I saw exceptions, I'll see if I find time to check these and will followup with reports. 

Thank you!
Hm, I admit I was only trying with JDK classes (which seemed to work OK, including navigator). Will try with other classes as well.

Just to prevent misunderstandings: The navigator and editor window work correctly if the class file is inside a jar. If the class file is outside a jar it can't be opened in the editor and the navigator window remains empty. This is really minor and I would not even consider it a regression, as the info in NB 8.2 was not really helpful:

![nb82](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/2179736/35403092-e7a7f734-01fe-11e8-9bea-d3a7b5afa83c.jpg)
![nb9](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/2179736/35403093-e7c9fe88-01fe-11e8-9e5e-84f99c6c49f2.jpg)

I would merge it as is.

@cowwoc I worked the entire day on multiple projects and could not make out the reason for the random longer (but not as long) delays. It might be that the in memory cache gets garbage collected (weakly referenced?) some times. But overall Netbeans is now quickly to respond. 

@jlahoda This patch helped a lot. I can actually use this version for development and didn't notice any new issues. Thank you.
@geertjanw @dbalek Time to merge? :)

I understand your point. However, questions have been asked about[1] this file and it seems strange to have bootstrap.css there, especially for one test only, so in this particular case, certainly not as a general rule, thought it best just to remove it.

[1]https://lists.apache.org/thread.html/5fdb996c8b25e5c48c47e4eca3942b656f690694d767d795524cc960@%3Cgeneral.incubator.apache.org%3E
Very interesting and useful. It looks to me like you're introducing a new API, AboutMessageOverride.
Just curious - have you somehow managed to get the build working on jdk9 ? Afaik the bootstrapping of javac 9 does not work.
Thanks for explaining - I agree with the assessment.
Tabs are used for indentation but 4 spaces should be used.

Ok, thanks for the advice and I will get those tabs converted next week.
I don't know how one would make a pluggable api for this, so I just made something using what I understand. The company I work for has a product that we release updates for rather rapidly. As such, I have a module whose main purpose is to keep track of the product's version. I used to overwrite the "netbeans.buildnumber" property when the module was started so the about window would look correct, but then that breaks the importing of settings. I figured that this was easier to do than to fix import/export settings.
Is there a recommended way to be naming branches when working on things?

Thanks for doing this! I didn't went through everything in detail yet, but overall seems good (maybe except the icons, where I don't know if that's correct).

Bertrand has asked if we can have a separate file for rat exclusions, so maybe we should ask about having (some) exclusions per module (which does make sense in a module world). OTOH, we could generate a complete "rat-exclusion.txt" automatically when doing the source build if needed.
Please see the "Contributor Guidelines" section at https://cwiki.apache.org/confluence/pages/viewpage.action?pageId=74681408
@jlahoda that file is here: https://github.com/apache/incubator-netbeans/blob/master/nbbuild/rat-exclusions.txt

@geertjanw - yes, I know. But this patch is moving some entries from that file into the individual licenseinfo.xml files. To me, that seems fine (and represents the modular structure). But we should check for reviewers think - we could e.g. generate a complete rat-exclusion.txt for the source distributions to make them easier to review (while still keeping licenseinfo.xml per module as needed).

@jlahoda I see where you are going. The summarized list of the `licenseinfo.xml` exclusions can be found in: `nbbuild/build/rat-licenseinfo.txt`. The `rat-exclusion.txt` is not yet incorporated, but it could also be integrated, turning that file into a "this was excluded from" rat report. Should I pull it in?

I also realized, that the generated report does not cover the correct set of files. While the rat report works through all the files (minus the explicit excludes), the ReportFromLicenseinfo is limited to the currently build cluster. I'll align these.
@matthiasblaesing I guess I'd start with asking what Bertrand and other mentors think.

After working with this patch for a longer time i came to the following conclusion:

- Overall code completion (everything) is much faster than without the patch
- Code completion for constructor arguments is quite slow (faster as without this patch, but still slow)

I hope to see this merged soon, since the constructor completion slowness should be a different issue.
@sdedic could you please have a look at this? According to the history you were the last one touching this code and I still don't see the intention of the unittest.
Sorry, I don't have much clue. My last commit was a simple test infrastructure refactoring, had nothing common with the test's semantic. @tzezula is IMHO better person to ask.
